a.g: [All] praise is [due] to Allah, who created the heavens and the earth and made the darkness and the light. Then those who disbelieve equate [others] with their Lord.
It is He who created you from clay and then decreed a term and a specified time [known] to Him; then [still] you are in dispute.
And He is Allah, [the only deity] in the heavens and the earth. He knows your secret and what you make public, and He knows that which you earn.
And no sign comes to them from the signs of their Lord except that they turn away therefrom.
For they had denied the truth when it came to them, but there is going to reach them the news of what they used to ridicule.

Have they not seen how many generations We destroyed before them which We had established upon the earth as We have not established you? And We sent [rain from] the sky upon them in showers and made rivers flow beneath them; then We destroyed them for their sins and brought forth after them a generation of others.
And even if We had sent down to you, [O Muhammad], a written scripture on a page and they touched it with their hands, the disbelievers would say, "This is not but obvious magic."
And they say, "Why was there not sent down to him an angel?" But if We had sent down an angel, the matter would have been decided; then they would not be reprieved.
And if We had made him an angel, We would have made him [appear as] a man, and We would have covered them with that in which they cover themselves.
And already were messengers ridiculed before you, but those who mocked them were enveloped by that which they used to ridicule.
Say, "Travel through the land; then observe how was the end of the deniers."

Say, "To whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and earth?" Say, "To Allah." He has decreed upon Himself mercy. He will surely assemble you for the Day of Resurrection, about which there is no doubt. Those who will lose themselves [that Day] do not believe.
And to Him belongs that which reposes by night and by day, and He is the Hearing, the Knowing.

Say, "Is it other than Allah I should take as a protector, Creator of the heavens and the earth, while it is He who feeds and is not fed?" Say, [O Muhammad], "Indeed, I have been commanded to be the first [among you] who submit [to Allah] and [was commanded], 'Do not ever be of the polytheists.' "
Say, "Indeed I fear, if I should disobey my Lord, the punishment of a tremendous Day."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
Indeed, this exception [istithna'] is valid, and it has four aspects. Two aspects are based on doubt [shakk], not in the root of faith [iman] but in its conclusion or its perfection, and two aspects are not based on doubt. The first aspect, which is not based on opposing doubt, is precaution against certainty [jazm] out of fear of what it contains of self-praise [tazkiyat al-nafs]. Allah, the Exalted, said: "So do not claim purity for yourselves" [53:32]. And He said: "Have you not seen those who claim purity for themselves?" [4:49]. And the Exalted said: "See how they invent lies about Allah" [4:50]. And it was said to a wise man, "What is ugly truthfulness?" He said, "A person's praise of himself." And faith [iman] is among the highest attributes of glory, and certainty [jazm] is absolute self-praise [tazkiya mutlaqa]. And the form of the exception is as if it is a burden for one who knows self-praise [tazkiya]; as it is said to a person, "You are a doctor, or a jurist, or an exegete," and he says, "Yes, if Allah wills," not in the manner of casting doubt, but to remove himself from praising himself. So the form is the form of hesitation and weakening of the report itself, and its meaning is the weakening necessitated by the prerequisites of the report, which is self-praise [tazkiya]. And by this interpretation, if he were asked about a blameworthy attribute, the exception would not be appropriate.

a.g: And among them are those who listen to you, but We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And if they should see every sign, they will not believe in it. Even when they come to you arguing with you, those who disbelieve say, "This is not but legends of the former peoples."
And they prevent [others] from him and are [themselves] remote from him. And they do not destroy except themselves, but they perceive [it] not.
If you could but see when they are made to stand before the Fire and will say, "Oh, would that we could be returned [to life on earth] and not deny the signs of our Lord and be among the believers."
But what they concealed before has [now] appeared to them. And even if they were returned, they would return to that which they were forbidden; and indeed, they are liars.
And they say, "There is none but our worldly life, and we will not be resurrected."

If you could but see when they will be made to stand before their Lord. He will say, "Is this not the truth?" They will say, "Yes, by our Lord." He will [then] say, "So taste the punishment because you used to disbelieve."

Those will have lost who deny the meeting with Allah, until when the Hour [of resurrection] comes upon them unexpectedly, they will say, "Oh, [how great is] our regret over what we neglected concerning it," while they bear their burdens on their backs. Unquestionably, evil is that which they bear.
And the worldly life is not but amusement and diversion; but the home of the Hereafter is best for those who fear Allah, so will you not reason?
We know that you, [O Muhammad], are saddened by what they say. And indeed, they do not call you untruthful, but it is the verses of Allah that the wrongdoers reject.

And certainly were messengers denied before you, but they were patient over [the effects of] denial, and they were harmed until Our victory came to them. And none can alter the words of Allah. And there has certainly come to you some information about the [previous] messengers.

And if their evasion is difficult for you, then if you are able to seek a tunnel into the earth or a stairway into the sky to bring them a sign, [then do so]. But if Allah had willed, He would have united them upon guidance. So never be of the ignorant.
Only those who hear will respond. But the dead - Allah will resurrect them; then to Him they will be returned.
And they say, "Why has a sign not been sent down to him from his Lord?" Say, "Indeed, Allah is Able to send down a sign, but most of them do not know."

And there is no creature on [or within] the earth or bird that flies with its wings except [that they are] communities like you. We have not neglected in the Register a thing. Then unto their Lord they will be gathered.

Indeed, and He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "And that was Our argument [hujjatuna] which We gave to Abraham against his people." And He, the Exalted, said in the story of Pharaoh: "And what is the Lord of the worlds?" up to His saying: "If you have come with something clear." And in summary, the Qur'an from its beginning to its end is a disputation [muhajjah] with the disbelievers. The foundation of the proofs of the theologians regarding Oneness [tawhid] is His saying, the Exalted: "If there were in them [the heavens and the earth] gods besides Allah, they would have been ruined." And regarding Prophethood: "And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our servant, then produce a surah like it." And regarding the Resurrection: "Say, 'He will give them life who produced them the first time.'" And other than these from the verses and proofs. And the Messengers, prayers of Allah be upon them, did not cease disputing [yuhajjuna] the deniers and arguing with them. He, the Exalted, said: "And argue with them in a way that is best." So the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, also used to dispute [yuhajjuna] the deniers and argue, but only when necessary, and the need for it was little in their time. And the first to establish the invitation of the innovators through argument [mujadalah] to the truth was 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, when he sent Ibn 'Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, to the Khawarij, and he spoke to them. He said, "What do you find fault with regarding your Imam?" They said, "He fought but did not take captives nor take spoils." He said, "That is regarding fighting the disbelievers. Tell me, if 'A'ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, were taken captive in the share of one of you, would you deem lawful from her what you deem lawful from your spoils, while she is your mother according to the clear text of the Book?" They said, "No." So two thousand of them returned to obedience through his argument [mujadalatihi]. And it is narrated that Al-Hasan debated [nadhar] a Qadari, so he retracted from Qadr. And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, debated [nadhar] a man from the Qadariyyah. And 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, debated [nadhar] Yazid ibn 'Umayrah regarding faith [iman]. 'Abdullah said, "If I said I am a believer [mu'min], I would be saying I am in Paradise." Yazid ibn 'Umayrah said to him, "O companion of the Messenger of Allah, this is a slip from you. Is faith [iman] not but that you believe in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Resurrection, the Balance, and you establish the prayer, fasting, and zakah? And we have sins; if we knew they would be forgiven for us, we would know we are from the people of Paradise. It is for that reason we say we are believers [mu'minun] and we do not say we are from the people of Paradise." Ibn Mas'ud said, "You have spoken the truth, by Allah. It is indeed a slip from me." Therefore, it should be said: Their delving into it was little, not much; and short, not long; and when necessary, not as a method.

a.g: And We gave to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob - all [of them] We guided. And Noah, We guided before; and among his descendants, David and Solomon and Job and Joseph and Moses and Aaron. Thus do We reward the doers of good.
And Zechariah and John and Jesus and Elias - and all were of the righteous.
And Ishmael and Elisha and Jonah and Lot - and all [of them] We preferred over the worlds.
And [some] among their fathers and their descendants and their brothers - and We chose them and We guided them to a straight path.
That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whomever He wills of His servants. But if they had associated others with Allah, then worthless for them would be whatever they were doing.
Those are the ones to whom We gave the Scripture and authority and prophethood. But if the disbelievers deny it, then We have entrusted it to a people who are not therein disbelievers.
Those are the ones whom Allah has guided, so from their guidance take an example. Say, "I ask of you for this message no payment. It is not but a reminder for the worlds."

And they did not appraise Allah with true appraisal when they said, "Allah did not reveal to a human being anything." Say, "Who revealed the Scripture that Moses brought as light and guidance to the people? You [Jews] make it into pages, disclosing [some of] it and concealing much. And you were taught that which you knew not - neither you nor your fathers." Say, "Allah [revealed it]." Then leave them in their [empty] discourse, amusing themselves.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Fasting
Indeed, the person of intellect [al-'aqil] eats the herb and does not inquire about the herb-garden. And whoever yearns to see his Beloved, his passionate love [ishq] preoccupies him from turning his attention to whether the vision is created in his eye or his forehead. Rather, he intends the vision and its delight, whether that is by the eye or otherwise. For the eye is a vessel and a container; there is no consideration of it, and it has no ruling. The truth in this is that the Eternal Power [al-Qudrah al-Azaliyyah] is vast, so it is not permissible for us to judge it as incapable of either of the two matters. This is regarding the ruling of permissibility. As for what is actualized in the Hereafter from among the permissible matters, it is not apprehended except by the revealed report [al-sam'], and the truth is what has become manifest to the People of the Sunnah and the Community from the evidences of the Sacred Law [shawahid al-shar']: that it is created in the eye so that the wording of 'vision' [ru'yah] and 'seeing' [nazar], and all the other terms mentioned in the Sacred Law, may be applied according to their apparent meaning. For it is not permissible to remove the apparent meanings except out of necessity. And God, the Exalted, knows best. **Clarification of the Causes that Strengthen the Love of God, the Exalted** Know that the happiest of creation in state in the Hereafter are the strongest of them in love [hubb] for God, the Exalted. For the meaning of the Hereafter is coming before God, the Exalted, and attaining the bliss of meeting Him. How immense is the bliss [na'im] of the lover when he comes before his Beloved after a long yearning! And he attains the permanence of witnessing Him [mushahadah] for all eternity, without any cause of vexation or disturbance, and without any overseer or rival, and without any fear of cessation! However, this bliss is according to the measure of the strength of the love [hubb]; whenever the love increases, the delight increases. The servant only acquires the love of God, the Exalted, in this world [al-dunya]. The foundation of love is inseparable from the believer, because it is inseparable from the foundation of knowledge [ma'rifah]. As for the strength of love and its domination until it reaches the rapturous passion which is called passionate love [ishq], that is what most people are separate from. That is only attained due to two causes: The first is severing the attachments of the world [ala'iq al-dunya] and expelling the love of other-than-God from the heart [qalb]. For the heart is like a vessel; it does not accommodate vinegar, for example, unless the water is removed from it. "God has not made for any man two hearts within his breast." The perfection of love is in loving God, the Mighty and Majestic, with all of his heart. As long as he turns his attention to other-than-Him, a corner of his heart is preoccupied with other-than-Him. To the extent he is preoccupied with other-than-God, the love of God diminishes from him. And to the extent water remains in the vessel, the vinegar poured into it diminishes. To this singling out [tafrid] and purification [tajrid] is the allusion in His statement, the Exalted: "Say, 'God,' then leave them in their discourse," and in His statement, the Exalted: "Indeed, those who have said, 'Our Lord is God,' and then remained steadfast." Rather, it is the meaning of your saying, "There is no god but God" [La ilaha illa Allah]â€”meaning, there is no object of worship [ma'bud] and no object of love [mahbub] except Him. For every object of love is an object of worship. For the servant [al-'abd] is the one bound, and the object of worship is what he is bound to. And every lover is bound by what he loves.

a.g: And this is a Book which We have sent down, blessed and confirming what was before it, that you may warn the Mother of Cities and those around it. Those who believe in the Hereafter believe in it, and they are maintaining their prayers.

And who is more unjust than one who invents a lie about Allah or says, "It has been inspired to me," while nothing has been inspired to him, and one who says, "I will reveal [something] like what Allah revealed." And if you could but see when the wrongdoers are in the overwhelming pangs of death while the angels extend their hands, [saying], "Discharge your souls! Today you will be awarded the punishment of [extreme] humiliation for what you used to say against Allah other than the truth and [that] you were, toward His verses, being arrogant."

[It will be said to them], "And you have certainly come to Us alone as We created you the first time, and you have left whatever We bestowed upon you behind you. And We do not see with you your 'intercessors' which you claimed that they were among you associates [of Allah]. It has [all] been severed between you, and lost from you is what you used to claim."

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
Indeed, in this resurrection [qiyamah], the servant ['abd] will be alone, and at that time it will be said: **"And you have come to Us alone, as We created you the first time"** (6:94). And in it, it will be said: **"Sufficient is yourself this Day against you as a reckoner"** (17:14). As for the Greater Resurrection [al-qiyamah al-kubra], which gathers all of creation, he will not be alone; rather, he will perhaps be called to account before an assembly of creation. And in it, the righteous [muttaqun] will be driven to Paradise and the criminals [mujrimun] to the Fire in groups, not as individuals. The first terror [al-hawl al-awwal] is the terror of the Minor Resurrection [qiyamah al-sughra], and for all the terrors of the Greater Resurrection there is a counterpart in the Minor Resurrection. Like the quaking of the earth [zalzalah al-ard], for example. Indeed, your own specific earth [arduka al-khassah] quakes in death. For you know that when a quaking befalls a town, it is truthful to say their earth has quaked, even if the surrounding lands have not quaked. Nay, if a person's dwelling alone quakes, the quaking has occurred in his regard, because he is only harmed by the quaking of all the earth through the quaking of his own dwelling, not by the quaking of another's dwelling. Thus, his portion [hissah] of the quaking has been fulfilled completely, without any diminishment.

The First Portion [al-ward al-awwal]: From the rising of the dawn [subh] until the rising of the sun. It is a noble time [waqt sharif], and its nobility and virtue are indicated by God the Exalted swearing by it when He said: "And by the dawn [subh] when it breathes" (81:18), and by His praising it when He said: "He who splits the dawn [isbah]" (6:96), and when He said: "Say, 'I seek refuge in the Lord of daybreak [falaq]'" (113:1). And He manifests His power in the drawing in of the shadow therein, when He the Exalted said: "Then We draw it in towards Ourselves, a gradual drawing in" (25:46). It is the time of drawing in the shadow of the night by spreading the light [nur] of the sun, and He guides people to glorify Him therein by His saying: "So glorify God when you reach the evening and when you rise at morn [tusbihun]" (30:17), and by His saying: "So glorify with praise of your Lord before the rising of the sun and before its setting" (50:39), and His saying, Mighty and Majestic: "And glorify Him during parts of the night and at the ends of the day, that you may be satisfied" (20:130), and His saying: "And remember the name of your Lord morning [bukratan] and evening [asila]" (76:25).

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
Indeed, the path to God [Allah] the Exalted is the vigilant observance of times [awqat] and their cultivation through constant devotional acts [awrad] in a manner of continuity. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The servants of God most beloved to God are those who observe the sun and the moon and the shadows for the remembrance [dhikr] of God the Exalted.' And He the Exalted has said: "The sun and the moon [move] by precise calculation [hisaban]" (6:96). And He the Exalted has said: "Have you not considered your Lordâ€”how He extends the shadow? If He willed, He could have made it stationary. Then We made the sun for it an indicator. Then We hold it in hand, a gentle seizing" (25:45-46). And He the Exalted has said: "And the moonâ€”We have determined for it phases [manazil]" (36:39). And He the Exalted has said: "And it is He who placed for you the stars that you may be guided by them through the darknesses [zulumat] of the land and sea" (6:97). So do not suppose that the purpose of the sun and the moon moving by a precise, ordered system, and of the creation of shadow and light and stars, is to seek aid through them for the affairs of the lower world [dunya]. Rather, it is so that you may know by them the measures of times [awqat] and thus occupy yourselves within them with acts of obedience [ta'at] and commerce for the Abode of the Hereafter [dar al-akhira]. What points you to this is His the Exalted's statement: "And it is He who has made the night and the day in succession for whoever desires to remember [dhikr] or desires gratitude [shukr]" (25:62). That is, one succeeds the other so that what was missed in one may be recovered in the other. And He made clear that this is for remembrance [dhikr] and gratitude [shukr], and nothing else. And He the Exalted said: "And We have made the night and the day two signs [ayatayn]. Then We erased the sign of the night and made the sign of the day visible that you may seek bounty [fadl] from your Lord and may know the number of years and the account [hisab]" (17:12). Indeed, know that perceptions [mudrakat] are divided into that which enters the imagination [khayal], such as imagined forms [suwar] and colored, shaped bodies [ajsam] of animal and plant individuals, and into that which does not enter the imagination [khayal], such as the Essence [dhat] of God, the Exalted, and all that is not a body [jism], like knowledge ['ilm], power [qudra], will [irada], and others. Therefore, the imagination [khayal] is the beginning of perception [idrak], and vision [ru'ya] is the completion [istikmal] of the perception [idrak] of the imagination [khayal], and it is the ultimate unveiling [kashf]. And that is called vision [ru'ya] because it is the ultimate unveiling [kashf], not because it is in the eye. And when you understand this regarding imaginable things, then know that the knowable things [ma'lumat] which also do not take form in the imagination [khayal] have two degrees for their knowledge [ma'rifa] and perception [idrak]: one is primary, and the second is a completion [istikmal] of it. And between the first and the second is a disparity in the increase of unveiling [kashf] and clarity [idah] like that between the imagined [mutakhayyal] and the seen [mar'i]. Thus, the second is also called, in relation to the first, witnessing [mushahada], meeting [liqa'], and vision [ru'ya]. And this naming is because vision [ru'ya] was called vision [ru'ya] because it is the ultimate unveiling [kashf]. And just as the custom [sunnah] of God, the Exalted, is established that the closing of the eyelids prevents the complete unveiling [kashf] through vision [ru'ya] and is a veil [hijab] between the sight [basar] and the seen [mar'i], and the veils [hujub] must be lifted for vision [ru'ya] to occurâ€”and what is not lifted, the perception [idrak] that occurs is mere imagination [takhayyul]â€”so too, by the requirement of the custom [sunnah] of God, the Exalted, as long as the soul [nafs] is veiled [mahjuba] by the accidents ['awarid] of the body [badan] and the demands of the appetites [shahawat] and the human qualities [sifat] that dominate it, it does not attain witnessing [mushahada] and meeting [liqa'] in the knowable things [ma'lumat] outside the imagination [khayal]. Rather, this life [hayat] is necessarily a veil [hijab] over it, like the veil [hijab] of the eyelids over the vision [ru'ya] of sights [absar]. And for that reason, He, the Exalted, said to Moses, peace be upon him: "You will not see Me," and He, the Exalted, said: "Eyesights [absar] do not perceive Him"â€”meaning in this world [dunya]. And the correct position is that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, did not see God, the Exalted, on the Night of the Ascension. So when the veil [hijab] is lifted by death, the soul [nafs] remains stained with the impurities [kudurat] of the world [dunya], not completely free from them, though they vary. Among them is that upon which filth [khabath] and rust [sada'] have accumulated, so it becomes like a mirror whose substance [jawhar] has been corrupted by the long accumulation of filth [khabath], so it does not accept rectification [islah] and polishing [tasqil]. These are the ones veiled [mahjubun] from their Lord for all eternityâ€”we seek refuge in God from that. And among us is that which has not reached the limit of the stain [rayn] and sealing [tab'] and has not left the capacity for purification [tazkiya] and polishing [tasqil]. So it is presented to the Fire [nar] in a presentation that suppresses from it the filth [khabath] with which it is soiled. And the presentation to the Fire [nar] is according to the need for purification [tazkiya], the least of it being a light moment, and the longest of itâ€”as the reports have statedâ€”being seven thousand years for the believers. And no soul [nafs] will depart from this world ['alam] except that it is accompanied by some dust [ghubra] and impurity [kudura], even if little. And for that reason, God, the Exalted, said: "And there is none of you but will come to it. This is upon your Lord an inevitability decreed. Then We will save those who feared God and leave the wrongdoers within it, on their knees." So every soul [nafs] is certain of arriving at the Fire [nar] and not certain of emerging from it. So when God completes its purification [tathir] and its purification [tazkiya], and the Book reaches its term, and the completion occurs of all that the Law [shar'] promised of the Reckoning [hisab], the Presentation ['ard], and other things, and the entitlement to Paradise [janna] arrivesâ€”and that is an ambiguous time [waqt mubham] which God has not informed any of His creation about, for it occurs after the Resurrection [qiyama]; and the time of the Resurrection [qiyama] is unknownâ€”then at that time, it becomes occupied with its purity [safa'] and its freedom from impurities [kudurat], where no dust [ghubra] or darkness [qatra] covers its face. For in it, the Truth [al-Haqq], glory and exaltation be to Him, is manifested [yatajalla]. So He is manifested [yatajalla] to it with a manifestation [tajalli] whose unveiling [inkishaf] in relation to what it knew is like the unveiling [inkishaf] of the mirror's manifestation [tajalli] in relation to what it imagined [takhayyala]. And this witnessing [mushahada] and manifestation [tajalli] is what is called vision [ru'ya]. Therefore, vision [ru'ya] is true [haqq], provided that what is understood from vision [ru'ya] is not the completion [istikmal] of the imagination [khayal] in a specific, imagined [mutakhayyal], conceived [mutasawwar] thing, particularized by direction [jiha] and place [makan]; for that is something from which the Lord of lords is greatly exalted. Rather, just as you knew Him in the world [dunya] with a true [haqiqiya], complete knowledge [ma'rifa] without imagination [takhayyul], conception [tasawwur], and estimation of shape [shakl] and form [sura], so you will see Him in the Hereafter [akhira] likewise. Rather, I say: The very knowledge [ma'rifa] attained in the world [dunya] is what is completed [istikmal], so it reaches the perfection [kamal] of unveiling [kashf] and clarity [wuduh].

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
Indeed, an exposition of the swift turning of the heart [qalb] and the division of hearts in changing and remaining firm. Know that the heart [qalb], as We have mentioned, is enveloped by the attributes We have described, and effects [athar] and states [ahwal] pour into it from the gates We have depicted. So it is as if it is a target, struck perpetually from every side. If something strikes it and it is affected by it, it is then struck from another side by what opposes it, and so its attribute changes. If a satan [shaytan] descends upon it, calling it to caprice [hawa], a king [malak] descends upon it, turning it away from that. And if one satan pulls it towards an evil, another satan pulls it towards another. And if a king pulls it towards a good, another pulls it towards another. So at times it is contested between two kings, and at times between two satans, and at times between a king and a satan. It is never left neglected. And to this is the allusion in His, the Exalted's, saying: "And We turn over their hearts [af'idah] and their sights." And because the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, had insight into the wondrous making of God, the Exalted, in the marvels of the heart [qalb] and its turning, he would swear by it, saying: "No, by the Turner of hearts [muqallib al-qulub]." And he would often say: "O Turner of hearts [muqallib al-qulub], make my heart [qalb] firm upon Your religion [din]." They said: "Do you fear, O Messenger of God?" He said: "And what makes me secure? The heart [qalb] is between two fingers of the fingers of the All-Merciful [al-Rahman]; He turns it as He wills." And in another wording: "If He wills to establish it, He establishes it, and if He wills to make it deviate, He makes it deviate."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
Indeed, just as the kernel [lubb] is precious in itself in relation to the husk, and it is the entire intended goal, yet it is not free from the admixture of its essence in relation to the pure oil extracted from it, so too is the Oneness of Action [tawhid al-fi'l] a lofty goal for the wayfarers [salikin], yet it is not free from the admixture of noticing the other and turning attention to multiplicity, in relation to one who witnesses nothing but the One, the True [al-Wahid al-Haqq]. If you say: How can it be conceived that nothing is witnessed except One, while he witnesses the sky and the earth and all other tangible bodies, and they are many? So how can the many be one? Then know that this is the ultimate aim of the sciences of unveilings ['ulum al-mukashafat]. And the secrets [asrar] of this knowledge are not permitted to be inscribed in a book, for the knowers [al-'arifun] have said: Disclosing the secret of Lordship [sirr al-rububiyya] is disbelief [kufr]. Furthermore, it is not connected to the science of transaction ['ilm al-mu'amala]. Yes, mentioning what can break the pattern of your rejection is possible. And it is that a thing can be many by one type of witnessing [mushahada] and consideration [i'tibar], and be one by another type of witnessing and consideration. This is just as a human being is many if one turns attention to his spirit [ruh] and his body [jasad] and his limbs [a'traf] and his veins ['uruq] and his bones ['izam] and his entrails [ahsha'], yet by another consideration and another witnessing he is one, for we say he is one human being. So in relation to humanity [insaniyya], he is one. And how many a person witnesses a human being, and the multiplicity of his intestines [am'a'] and veins and limbs and the details of his spirit and body and organs does not cross his mind. The difference between them is that in the state of absorption [istighraq] and being enraptured by him, he is absorbed in a One in which there is no separation, as if he is in the very eye of union ['ayn al-jam']. And the one who turns attention to multiplicity is in separation [tafriq]. So likewise, everything in existence [wujud] from the Creator [al-Khaliq] and the creation [al-makhluq] has many different considerations and witnessings. So by one of the considerations, it is one, and by other considerations, it is many, and some of them are more intensely multiple than others. Its example is the human being, even though it does not perfectly match the intended goal, yet it alerts in general to how multiplicity becomes, in the ruling of witnessing, one. And by this speech, it becomes clear to abandon denial and rejection [juhud] of a station [maqam] which your faith [iman] of affirmation [tasdiq] has not reached. Thus, for you, by virtue of being a believer in this Oneness [tawhid], there is a share [nasib], even if what you have believed in is not your attribute [sifa], just as when you believe in prophethood [nubuwwa] even though you are not a prophet, you have a share from it according to the strength of your faith [iman]. And this witnessing [mushahada] in which nothing appears except the One, the True, is attained through the expansion [inshirah] of the breast [sadr] and its opening [infisah] and the shining [ishraq] of the Light [nur] of the Truth [al-Haqq] within it. For that expansion is what is intended by His saying, the Exalted: "So whoever Allah wills to guide, He expands his breast to Islam [al-Islam]" and by His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "Is he whose breast Allah has expanded to Islam, so he is upon a light from his Lord..."

Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said: "Say, 'Then to Allah belongs the conclusive argument [al-hujjah al-balighah].'" And how could the mention of the argument [al-hujjah] and the demand for it and the investigation into it be forbidden when Allah the Exalted has said: "Say, 'Produce your proof [burhanakum],'" and the Almighty has said: "So that he who would perish might perish upon clear evidence [baiyinah] and he who would live might live upon clear evidence [baiyinah]," and He the Exalted said: "Do you have any authority [sultan] for this?" meaning any proof [hujjah] and evidence [burhan]. And He the Exalted said: "Say, 'Then to Allah belongs the conclusive argument [al-hujjah al-balighah],'" and He the Exalted said: "Have you not considered the one who argued with Abraham about his Lord..." up to His saying: "So the disbeliever was confounded," when He, glorified be He, mentioned Abraham's argumentation [ihtijaj] and his disputation [mujadalah] and his silencing of his opponent in the context of praising him. And the Almighty said: "And that was Our argument [hujjatuna] which We gave Abraham against his people." And He the Exalted said: "They said, 'O Noah, you have disputed [jadaltana] with us and been abundant in your dispute [jidalana] with us.'" And He the Exalted said in the story of Pharaoh: "And what is the Lord of the worlds?" up to His saying: "If you should come with something clear [mubin]." And in summary, the Qur'an from its beginning to its end is argumentation [muhajjah] with the disbelievers. The foundation of the theologians' proofs in [the matter of] Oneness [tawhid] is His saying: "If there had been within them gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined." And in [the matter of] Prophethood [nubuwwah]: "And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our servant, then produce a surah the like thereof." And in [the matter of] the Resurrection [ba'th]: "Say, 'He will give it life who produced it the first time,'" and other such verses and proofs. And the Messengers, prayers of Allah be upon them, never ceased to argue [yuhajjuna] with the deniers and dispute [yujadilunahum] with them. He the Exalted said: "And argue [jadilhum] with them in a way that is best." So the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, also used to argue [yuhajjuna] with the deniers and dispute [yujadiluna] with them, but only when necessary, and the need for it was little in their time. And the first to institute the invitation of the innovators [al-mubtadi'ah] to the truth through disputation [mujadalah] was 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, when he sent Ibn 'Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, to the Khawarij, and he spoke to them. He said, "What do you find fault with regarding your Imam?" They said, "He fought but did not take captives nor take spoils." He said, "That was in fighting the disbelievers. Tell me, if 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her, were among the spoils for one of you, would you deem lawful for her what you deem lawful from your property, when she is your mother according to the clear text of the Book?" They said, "No." So two thousand of them returned to obedience through his disputation [mujadalatihi]. And it is narrated that Al-Hasan debated [nadhar] a Qadari, so he retracted from [belief in] Predestination [al-qadar]. And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, debated [nadhar] a man from the Qadariyyah. And 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, debated [nadhar] Yazid ibn 'Umayrah concerning faith [al-iman]. 'Abdullah said, "If I said, 'I am a believer [mu'min],' I would be saying, 'I am in Paradise.'" Yazid ibn 'Umayrah said to him, "O companion of the Messenger of Allah, this is a slip from you. Is faith [al-iman] anything but that you believe in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Resurrection [al-ba'th] and the Scale, and that you establish the prayer, fasting, and zakah? And we have sins; if we knew they would be forgiven for us, we would know we are among..."

a.g: Say, [O Muhammad], "Bring forward your witnesses who will testify that Allah has prohibited this." And if they testify, do not testify with them. And do not follow the desires of those who deny Our verses and those who do not believe in the Hereafter, while they equate [others] with their Lord.

Say, "Come, I will recite what your Lord has prohibited to you. [He commands] that you not associate anything with Him, and to parents, good treatment, and do not kill your children out of poverty; We will provide for you and them. And do not approach immoralities - what is apparent of them and what is concealed. And do not kill the soul which Allah has forbidden [to be killed] except by [legal] right. This has He instructed you that you may use reason."

And do not approach the orphan's property except in a way that is best until he reaches maturity. And give full measure and weight in justice. We do not charge any soul except [with that within] its capacity. And when you testify, be just, even if [it concerns] a near relative. And the covenant of Allah fulfill. This has He instructed you that you may remember.
And, [moreover], this is My path, which is straight, so follow it; and do not follow [other] ways, for you will be separated from His way. This has He instructed you that you may become righteous.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
Indeed, the servant [al-'abd] in this is like a traveler who remains in a vast wilderness of many paths, of obscure ways, on a dark night. He can scarcely know the way except with a seeing eye [al-'ayn al-basirah] and the rising of a shining sun. And the seeing eye here is the heart [al-qalb] purified by God-consciousness [al-taqwa], and the shining sun is the abundant knowledge [al-'ilm al-ghazir] derived from the Book of Allah, the Exalted, and the Sunnah of His Messenger, peace be upon him, which guides to the hidden intricacies of its paths. Otherwise, its paths are many and obscure. Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, drew a line for us one day and said, 'This is the path of Allah.' Then he drew lines to the right of the line and to its left, then said, 'These are paths; upon every path among them is a devil calling to it.' Then he recited: 'And verily, this is My straight path [sirati mustaqiman], so follow it, and do not follow [other] paths, lest they separate you from His way.'" Thus, he, peace be upon him, made clear the multitude of its paths.

a.g: Then We gave Moses the Scripture, making complete [Our favor] upon the one who did good and as a detailed explanation of all things and as guidance and mercy that perhaps in [the matter of] the meeting with their Lord they would believe.
And this [Qur'an] is a Book We have revealed [which is] blessed, so follow it and fear Allah that you may receive mercy.
[We revealed it] lest you say, "The Scripture was only sent down to two groups before us, but we were of their study unaware,"

Or lest you say, "If only the Scripture had been revealed to us, we would have been better guided than they." So there has [now] come to you a clear evidence from your Lord and a guidance and mercy. Then who is more unjust than one who denies the verses of Allah and turns away from them? We will recompense those who turn away from Our verses with the worst of punishment for their having turned away.

Do they [then] wait for anything except that the angels should come to them or your Lord should come or that there come some of the signs of your Lord? The Day that some of the signs of your Lord will come no soul will benefit from its faith as long as it had not believed before or had earned through its faith some good. Say, "Wait. Indeed, we [also] are waiting."

Indeed, those who have divided their religion and become sects - you, [O Muhammad], are not [associated] with them in anything. Their affair is only [left] to Allah; then He will inform them about what they used to do.

Whoever comes [on the Day of Judgement] with a good deed will have ten times the like thereof [to his credit], and whoever comes with an evil deed will not be recompensed except the like thereof; and they will not be wronged.
Say, "Indeed, my Lord has guided me to a straight path - a correct religion - the way of Abraham, inclining toward truth. And he was not among those who associated others with Allah."
Say, "Indeed, my prayer, my rites of sacrifice, my living and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds.
No partner has He. And this I have been commanded, and I am the first [among you] of the Muslims."

Say, "Is it other than Allah I should desire as a lord while He is the Lord of all things? And every soul earns not [blame] except against itself, and no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you concerning that over which you used to differ."

And it is He who has made you successors upon the earth and has raised some of you above others in degrees [of rank] that He may try you through what He has given you. Indeed, your Lord is swift in penalty; but indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful.
